Fold the sides of the phyllo over the filling, then fold the bottom edge of the phyllo over the filling. Roll up jelly-roll style and carefully transfer to the prepared baking sheet, seam side down. Repeat the process with the remaining phyllo sheets and apple filling. Brush the top of the strudels with the remaining butter. cucumber in half and then slice each half down the middle lengthwise. Use the tip of a teaspoon to scoop out the center seeds. Cut each half into thin slices and place in a colander along with the red onion slices. Toss with salt and let sit in the sink for at least 30 minutes, until the water drains out.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/grilled-salmon-with-creamy-cucumber-dill-salad.html#fv-recipe-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In the meantime, make the dressing: combine the sour cream, mayonnaise, white wine vinegar, dill, garlic, sugar and black pepper in a medium bowl and mix well.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/grilled-salmon-with-creamy-cucumber-dill-salad.html#fv-recipe-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the cucumbers and onions are ready, release any excess water by tapping the colander on the base of the sink, then use a large wad of paper towels to pat the vegetables dry. Add to the dressing and toss well. Cover and chill until ready to serve.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/grilled-salmon-with-creamy-cucumber-dill-salad.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the grill to medium-high heat. Clean the grill rack, then brush with oil. Close the lid and let return to temperature. Rub the salmon with olive oil and season generously with kosher salt and pepper. Place the fillets skin side down and grill until golden brown and slightly charred, 4 to 5 minutes (resist the urge to peek or flip early; when fillets are nicely seared on the first side, they should release easily). Flip the fillets over and continue grilling until done, 2 to 3 minutes. Let cool slightly, remove the skin if desired, and serve with the cold cucumber-dill salad piled over top or alongside.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/grilled-salmon-with-creamy-cucumber-dill-salad.html#fv-recipe-step-4"}], "recipeIngredient": ["4 (6-oz) salmon fillets, skin on", "1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil", "\u00be teaspoon kosher salt", "\u00bd teaspoon freshly ground black pepper", "1 English cucumber (also called hothouse cucumber)", "\u2153 cup finely sliced red onion, from one small red onion", "\u00bd teaspoon salt", "\u00bc cup plus 2 tablespoons sour cream", "3 tablespoons mayonnaise, best quality such as Hellmann's or Duke's", "2 tablespoons white wine vinegar", "\u00bc cup chopped fresh dill", "1 clove garlic, minced", "\u00bd teaspoon sugar", " Freshly ground black pepper, to taste"], "recipeYield": "4", "image": ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2011/08/Grilled-Salmon-11-1200x1500.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2011/08/Grilled-Salmon-11-500x500.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2011/08/Grilled-Salmon-11-500x375.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2011/08/Grilled-Salmon-11-480x270.jpg"], "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "ratingValue": 4.96, "ratingCount": "78"}, "datePublished": "2023-08-22T08:16:48-04:00", "keywords": "Grill, Salmon, Spring, Summer, White Wine Vinegar", "recipeCuisine": "Middle Eastern", "recipeCategory": "Recipes"}]

["https://www.onceuponachef.com/about-jenn-segal"]}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640052977", "position": 1, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640052977", "name": "What kind of turkey should I buy?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "There are a few types of turkeys you\u2019ll typically see in stores: natural or plain, self-basting or injected, or kosher turkeys. Natural turkeys haven\u2019t been pre-treated in any way, while self-basting and kosher birds have already been salted or injected with a brining solution to keep them juicy.<br/>For most recipes (including the one below), a plain, untreated turkey gives you the most control over seasoning. That said, if you can only find a self-basting or kosher bird, don\u2019t worry\u2014you can absolutely still make any turkey recipe. Just keep in mind that these birds already contain salt, so if using a brine, you may want to dial back the salt to avoid over-salting.<br/>You may also come across organic, free-range, or heritage turkeys, which usually have excellent flavor but can be leaner and cook a little faster.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640077572", "position": 2, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640077572", "name": "How much turkey should I count on per person?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "A good rule of thumb is about 1\u00bd to 2 pounds of turkey per person if you\u2019re buying a whole bird. That accounts for both the bones and the meat. If you want plenty of leftovers for sandwiches or soups the next day, lean toward the higher end of that range. For example, a 14-pound turkey comfortably serves about 8 to 10 people with leftovers.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640099075", "position": 3, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640099075", "name": "How long should a frozen turkey thaw?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "The safest method is to let the turkey thaw slowly in the refrigerator. Plan on about 24 hours of thawing time for every 4 pounds of turkey. So, for a bird in the 12 to 14 pound range, you\u2019ll want to start the process 3 to 4 days before roasting. This steady, hands-off approach keeps the meat at a safe temperature as it defrosts.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640115397", "position": 4, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640115397", "name": "Should I rinse my turkey?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Nope\u2014it\u2019s best not to. Rinsing a raw turkey can actually spread bacteria around your sink and counters. Any surface bacteria will cook off in the oven, so just pat the bird dry with paper towels before brining or seasoning.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640138737", "position": 5, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640138737", "name": "What's the difference between wet and dry brining?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Dry brining involves rubbing salt, herbs, and spices onto the turkey skin and letting it rest in the fridge overnight (or longer). In contrast, wet brining requires soaking the turkey in a seasoned saltwater solution, which often means dealing with a large cooler or bag\u2014a process that can be quite cumbersome. Both methods enhance flavor and juiciness, but dry brining is much simpler and produces beautifully crisp skin.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640159060", "position": 6, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640159060", "name": "Should the turkey be roasted with the stuffing inside?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "It\u2019s best to cook the stuffing separately rather than inside the turkey. Not only does this reduce food safety risks (since the stuffing needs to reach a safe temperature along with the meat), but it also ensures the stuffing comes out golden and crisp on top instead of soggy. Bonus: your turkey will also cook more evenly and a bit faster.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640183404", "position": 7, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640183404", "name": "Should I tie the turkey legs together or keep them clipped/trussed?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "If your turkey comes with the legs tucked into a metal or plastic clip, or held together by a small flap of skin, it\u2019s best to remove it before roasting. Leaving the legs bound prevents heat from circulating properly, which can cause the inner thighs to cook more slowly. Let the legs rest naturally\u2014this helps the turkey cook more evenly and ensures the meat near the cavity is fully done.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640200113", "position": 8, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640200113", "name": "Should I baste my turkey?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "You don\u2019t need to\u2014and honestly, it can do more harm than good. Every time you open the oven to baste, you let out heat and extend the cooking time. Plus, basting doesn\u2019t actually make the meat juicier; it just helps the skin brown. A dry-brined turkey already has plenty of flavor and moisture built in, and the butter rub before roasting gives you that beautifully golden, crisp skin without all the fuss.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640234656", "position": 9, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640234656", "name": "How much time does a turkey need to roast?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "It depends on the size of the bird, but generally you\u2019ll be looking at a few hours. Smaller turkeys cook more quickly at a steady temperature, while larger ones benefit from a two-stage method\u2014starting at a higher temperature to brown the skin, then lowering the heat so the meat cooks evenly.<br/><br/>Rather than relying strictly on minutes per pound, it\u2019s best to use a thermometer: the breast should register <strong>165\u00b0F</strong> and the thighs <strong>175\u00b0F</strong> when done. Keep in mind that the temperature will rise several degrees as the turkey rests (carryover cooking).<br/><br/>To avoid any guesswork, use a <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/ThermoPro-Digital-Cooking-Thermometer-Stainless/dp/B017613C3C/ref=sr_1_1?s=home-garden&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1481656902&amp;sr=1-1&amp;keywords=leave%2Bin%2Bcooking%2Bthermometer&amp;th=1\">digital thermometer</a> with a leave-in probe and remote monitor so you can track the temperature without ever opening the oven.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640286411", "position": 10, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640286411", "name": "Where should I check the turkey\u2019s temperature?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "To check the breast, insert the thermometer into the deepest part of the meat, holding it parallel to the bird from the neck end. Avoid touching the bone\u2014it can give a false high reading. For the thigh, insert the thermometer into the thickest part of the meat near the hip joint, again avoiding the bone.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640305697", "position": 11, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640305697", "name": "Should the turkey be covered while it roasts?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Not at the start. The bird should go into the oven uncovered so the skin can dry out and crisp as it cooks. After about 90 minutes, if the skin is browning too quickly, the turkey can be tented loosely with foil to prevent it from getting too dark before the meat is fully cooked. This approach gives you the best of both worlds: beautifully golden skin and evenly cooked, juicy meat.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640334966", "position": 12, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640334966", "name": "How long should the turkey rest before carving?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "At least 20 to 30 minutes. This gives the juices time to redistribute, keeping the meat moist when you carve it. Cover it loosely with foil to keep it warm\u2014the internal temperature will continue to rise slightly as it rests.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640346787", "position": 13, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640346787", "name": "Can turkey be roasted ahead of time?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes, you can absolutely roast it in advance to make the big day less hectic. Just keep in mind that the skin won\u2019t stay as crisp once it\u2019s reheated, but the meat will still be tender and flavorful. Detailed instructions for making ahead and reheating are included in the recipe card.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}]}, {"@context": "https://slickstream.com", "@graph": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove and discard the truss that holds turkey legs together (if the legs are held together with turkey skin, cut the skin to release them). Trim off and discard any excess fat in the neck or body cavity. Remove giblets and neck; discard or save for stock. Pat the turkey dry with paper towels.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, mix the sugar, salt, thyme, sage, and pepper for the dry brine. Place the turkey on the rack of the prepared baking sheet. Rub and pat the dry brine all over the turkey, including inside the cavity. Refrigerate, uncovered, for at least 24 hours and up to 48 hours. (For food safety, ensure the turkey remains in the refrigerator at 40\u00b0F or lower during the entire brining period. If brining for longer than 24 hours, you can cover the turkey loosely with plastic wrap for the first part of the brining process and then uncover it for the final 24 hours to allow the skin to dry.)", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F and set an oven rack in the lower third of the oven. Using damp paper towels, brush the dry brine off the turkey's exterior (keep the brine as-is in the turkey's cavity).", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scatter the onion, carrots, and celery in the bottom of a large roasting pan. Place a roasting rack inside the pan and place the turkey on the rack. Tuck the wings underneath the bird. Using your hands, smear the butter all over the turkey. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roast the turkey until the skin is deep golden and a leave-in or instant-read thermometer registers 165\u00b0F (74\u00b0C) in the thickest part of the breast and 175\u00b0F (80\u00b0C) in the thigh, 1\u00be to 2\u00bd hours. Check the turkey after about 1\u00bd hours; if the skin is browning too quickly, cover it loosely with foil.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using clean oven mitts that you don't mind getting dirty (silicone grilling gloves or mitts work well), carefully tilt the turkey so any juices from the cavity pour into the roasting pan. Remove the vegetables from the pan and discard (or if they aren't too soft/brown, save them and arrange on the serving platter with the turkey). Reserve the drippings in the pan for the gravy.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While the turkey rests, make the <a href=\"https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/homemade-gravy.html\">gravy</a>.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Carve the turkey and serve with the gravy on the side. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "<strong>Make-Ahead Instructions:</strong> If you don't mind losing the crispy skin, the turkey can be roasted and carved ahead of time. Pour a thin layer of the gravy into an ovenproof serving dish. Arrange the carved turkey nicely on top of the gravy; cover tightly with plastic wrap and refrigerate for up to two days. Refrigerate the remaining gravy in a separate container. To reheat: remove the plastic wrap and cover the platter with aluminum foil. Place in a 325\u00b0F-oven for 20 to 30 minutes, until the turkey is hot. Reheat the gravy in the microwave or on the stovetop.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "<strong>Note on Selecting Your Turkey:</strong> For the best results with this dry-brining method, look for a turkey that is not injected, kosher, or labeled as \"self-basting.\" These types of turkeys have already been treated with salt or a brining solution. However, if your bird has been treated, you can absolutely still use this recipe, as these birds do still benefit from additional seasoning. Just halve the amount of salt in the dry brine to avoid over-salting.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "<strong>Note:</strong> I've given a range for the cooking time, which will depend on the size of your turkey. ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/about-jenn-segal"]}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/balsamic-vinaigrette.html#faq-question-1711030610870", "position": 1, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/balsamic-vinaigrette.html#faq-question-1711030610870", "name": "Can I freeze balsamic vinaigrette?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Technically, you can freeze it, but it's not ideal. Olive oil can solidify and change texture in the freezer, affecting the overall quality. It keeps nicely at room temperature in a jar or other airtight container for up to 4 days. If you'd like to extend the shelf life, you can refrigerate it for up to a week. Just make sure you give it a shake to re-emulsify before using.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/balsamic-vinaigrette.html#faq-question-1711036061765", "position": 2, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/balsamic-vinaigrette.html#faq-question-1711036061765", "name": "Can balsamic vinaigrette be used as a marinade for chicken?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Sure, that should work! However, because the dressing has vinegar in it (which is acidic), it will do best with either bone-in chicken pieces or dark meat. Acidic marinades are generally too harsh for lean white meats like boneless skinless chicken breasts; they will give the meat a leathery texture. ", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Balsamic Vinaigrette", "author": {"@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/#/schema/person/d09ca52c9e790675f71c46404845af62"}, "description": "My go-to balsamic vinaigrette\u2014perfect for drizzling over fresh greens, juicy tomatoes, creamy mozzarella, and more.", "datePublished": "2022-03-30T11:07:24+00:00", "image": ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2022/03/balsamic-vinaigrette-scaled.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2022/03/balsamic-vinaigrette-scaled-500x500.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2022/03/balsamic-vinaigrette-scaled-500x375.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2022/03/balsamic-vinaigrette-scaled-480x270.jpg"], "recipeYield": ["4", "4 to 6 small salads (\u00be cup dressing)"], "prepTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT10M", "recipeIngredient": ["1 tablespoon Dijon mustard", "1  small clove garlic, (finely minced)", "1 tablespoon finely minced shallot, (from 1 small shallot)", "\u00bd teaspoon salt", "\u00bc teaspoon freshly ground black pepper", "1\u00bd teaspoons sugar", "3 tablespoons balsamic vinegar", "\u00bd cup extra virgin olive oil"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the mustard, garlic, shallot, salt, freshly ground black pepper, sugar and balsamic vinegar. While whisking vigorously, slowly pour in the oil to create an emulsion; the dressing should be slightly thickened and emulsified when all the oil is added. Taste and adjust seasoning, if necessary. Store the vinaigrette in a jar at room temperature for up to 4 days. Shake to re-emulsify when ready to use.", "name": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the mustard, garlic, shallot, salt, freshly ground black pepper, sugar and balsamic vinegar. While whisking vigorously, slowly pour in the oil to create an emulsion; the dressing should be slightly thickened and emulsified when all the oil is added. Taste and adjust seasoning, if necessary. Store the vinaigrette in a jar at room temperature for up to 4 days. "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the Dough: In a large bowl, whisk together the melted butter, warm water, sugar, salt and yeast. Add the eggs and egg yolk and whisk until evenly combined. Add the flour all at once and stir with a wooden spoon until the mixture is uniform; it will be wet, lumpy, and a bit elastic (it will firm up in the fridge and smooth out when you knead it). Cover loosely with plastic wrap (make sure the entire bowl is covered but don't seal it airtight) and let sit at room temperature for 2 hours, then refrigerate for at least 3 hours or up to 3 days.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F and set an oven rack in the middle position. Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange the pecans on the prepared baking sheet. Bake for 7 to 10 minutes, until fragrant and toasted. Transfer the pecans to a plate to cool. Leave the foil on the baking sheet; you'll use it again. (Shut off the oven.)", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the caramel filling: In a medium bowl, whisk together the butter, brown sugar, honey, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt. Mix until thickened and all of the butter is absorbed.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9-inch square cake pan with butter, then spread half the caramel mixture (about \u215e cup) evenly over the bottom. Scatter half (1 cup) of the pecans over the caramel mixture and set aside. Transfer the remaining pecans to a cutting board and chop finely (these will go into the filling).", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Assemble the Sticky Buns: Remove the dough from the refrigerator. Dust a clean work surface generously with flour. Scrape the dough out of the bowl and place on the work surface. Dust the dough with flour and knead, sprinkling more flour as necessary so the dough doesn't stick, for about 30 seconds.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll out the dough to an 1\u20448-inch-thick rectangle, about 14x12 inches, adding more flour under and over the dough, as needed, to prevent it from sticking.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using an offset spatula, spread the remaining caramel mixture evenly over the rolled-out dough, leaving a \u00bd-inch border. Sprinkle the finely chopped pecans evenly over top. Starting with the long side, roll the dough into a log and pinch the seam closed. Press the ends in so the log is an even thickness throughout.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a sharp serrated knife, cut the log into 8 equal pieces and arrange over the pecans and caramel in the prepared pan, so that the swirled cut edge is facing upward. Allow to rest for 1 hour on the counter, loosely covered with plastic wrap. They will rise just a bit. (Alternatively, place the pan in the refrigerator overnight and let sit out at room temperature for 1 hour before baking the next day.)", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the cake pan on the foil-lined baking sheet, in case the caramel bubbles over, and bake for 40 to 45 minutes, or until golden brown and well set in the center (a toothpick or cake tester inserted into the center shouldn't have any wet bits of dough on it). While still very hot, run a knife around the outer edge of the pan to release the caramel rolls, and invert immediately onto a large serving dish or sheet pan lined with parchment paper. The warm topping will drip down the sides. (If you let the buns sit too long, they will stick to the pan and be difficult to turn out.) Let the buns cool slightly and serve warm. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you have leftover rolls, transfer them to a clean plate (the caramel underneath will cause them to stick), cover tightly with foil, and store at room temperature for up to 2 days. Reheat the sticky buns, covered with foil, in a 350\u00b0F oven until warmed through.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Freezer-Friendly Instructions: After the 3-hour rise in the refrigerator, freeze the dough in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks. When ready to bake, thaw the dough in the refrigerator for 24 hours before using, then proceed with assembling the sticky buns.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Note: Warm water helps activate the yeast. The temperature should be about 110\u00b0F, but it doesn't need to be exact so no need to use a thermometer; just try to get it to about the temperature of bath water.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sticky-buns.html#fv-recipe-step-14"}], "recipeIngredient": ["1 stick (\u00bd cup) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled, plus more for greasing the pan", "\u00bd cup  warm water (see note)", "\u00bc cup  granulated sugar", "1\u215b teaspoons salt", "1 teaspoon  rapid-rise/instant yeast", "2 large eggs", "1  egg yolk", "2\u00be cups all-purpose flour, spooned into measuring cup and leveled-off, plus more for kneading and rolling", "1\u00bd sticks (\u00be cup) unsalted butter, melted, plus more for greasing the pan", "1\u00bc cups (packed) light brown sugar", "\u2153 cup  honey", "1 teaspoon  cinnamon", "\u00bc teaspoon  ground nutmeg", " \u00bd teaspoon  salt", "2 cups  whole pecans, divided"], "recipeYield": "8", "image": ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2022/04/pecan-sticky-buns-1200x1627.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2022/04/pecan-sticky-buns-scaled-500x500.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2022/04/pecan-sticky-buns-scaled-500x375.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2022/04/pecan-sticky-buns-scaled-480x270.jpg"], "citation": "Adapted from <a href=\"https://artisanbreadinfive.com/buying-our-books/\">The New Artisan Bread in Five Minutes a Day</a> by Jeff Hertzberg and Zo\u00eb Fran\u00e7ois", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "ratingValue": 5, "ratingCount": "10"}, "datePublished": "2022-04-14T06:55:33-04:00", "keywords": "All Seasons, Comfort Food, Easter, Mother's Day, New Year's Day", "recipeCuisine": "American, German", "recipeCategory": "Recipes"}]

"While technically you can freeze it, I wouldn't necessarily recommend it. Basil tends to lose its vibrant flavor and aroma when frozen, and the texture of the vinaigrette might change upon thawing. homemade pie crust or 9-inch deep-dish frozen pie crust shell", "1  (15-oz) can pure pumpkin (about 1\u00be cups)", "1  large egg", "3  large eggs yolks", "\u00bd cup granulated sugar", "\u00bd cup "HowToStep", "text": "Blind Bake the Crust: If you\u2019re using a store-bought frozen crust, follow the blind-baking instructions on the package. If you\u2019re using a homemade crust, roll out the dough and gently fit it into a 9-inch deep-dish pie pan, making sure it\u2019s snug against the bottom and sides. Chill the crust for at least 30 minutes.Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F and set an oven rack in the middle position. Place the chilled crust on a baking sheet (it makes it much easier to move in and out of the oven). Line the crust with a piece of parchment paper and fill it about three-quarters full with dried beans or pie weights.Bake for 20 minutes. Remove the crust from the oven, lift out the parchment and weights, and tent the edges with a few strips of foil folded in half lengthwise to keep them from getting too dark. Return the crust to the oven and bake for another 15 to 20 minutes, until the bottom looks dry and lightly golden. If it puffs up a bit, just press it down gently with a flat spatula\u2014try not to puncture it. Remove the foil, but keep it nearby in case you need it again later.After blind-baking the crust, reduce the oven temperature to 325\u00b0F.", "name": "Blind Bake the Crust: If you\u2019re using a store-bought frozen crust, follow the blind-baking instructions on the package. If you\u2019re using a homemade crust, roll out the dough and gently fit it into a 9-inch deep-dish pie pan, making sure it\u2019s snug against the bottom and sides. Chill the crust for at least 30 minutes.Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F and set an oven rack in the middle position. Place the chilled crust on a baking sheet (it makes it much easier to move in and out of the oven). Line the crust with a piece of parchment paper and fill it about three-quarters full with dried beans or pie weights.Bake for 20 minutes. Remove the crust from the oven, lift out the parchment and weights, and tent the edges with a few strips of foil folded in half lengthwise to keep them from getting too dark. Return the crust to the oven and bake for another 15 to 20 minutes, until the bottom looks dry and lightly golden. If it puffs up a bit, just press it down gently with a flat spatula\u2014try not to puncture it. Remove the foil, but keep it nearby in case you need it again later.After blind-baking the crust, reduce the oven temperature to 325\u00b0F.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/perfect-pumpkin-pie.html#wprm-recipe-76491-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the Filling: In a large bowl, combine the pumpkin, egg, egg yolks, granulated sugar, brown sugar, flour, salt, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, cloves, pepper, and evaporated milk. It should look dry around the edges, but the center should jiggle just slightly if you nudge the pan. Keep a close eye on the pie as it bakes; if ever the crust looks like it&#39;s browning too quickly, tent the edges with foil strips. Let the pie cool on a rack (leave it on the baking sheet) to room temperature, a few hours. Add the chunks of cold butter, then pulse a few times until the mixture resembles coarse meal with some pea-size chunks of butter within. (Alternatively, this can be done by hand using a pastry cutter or your fingers.)", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sweet-potato-biscuits.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the flour mixture to the bowl with the sweet potato mixture. Using a rubber spatula, fold until the mixture is just moistened and holds together, adding up to 2 more tablespoons of milk if needed; do not overwork the dough.  ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sweet-potato-biscuits.html#fv-recipe-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Sprinkle a small handful of flour on a clean work surface. Turn the dough out onto the surface and knead lightly 3 or 4 times with the palm of your hand until the mixture comes together into a smooth ball. Pat the dough into a rectangle about \u00be inch thick. Using a sharp knife, cut the dough into thirds. Stack the pieces on top of one another and pat out into a rectangle about \u00be in thick again, flouring the surface lightly as needed to prevent the dough from sticking.\r\nCut the dough into thirds again, and stack the pieces on top of one another. Pat into another rectangle with a final thickness of about \u00be inch. Dust the blade of a sharp knife with flour and cut the dough into twelve even squares (they will seem small). Transfer the squares to the prepared baking sheet and bake for 13 to 15 minutes, until the biscuits are lightly golden on top and golden on the bottom. The biscuits are best served warm out of the oven (though a few minutes in the oven will revive slightly older biscuits).", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/sweet-potato-biscuits.html#fv-recipe-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, beat together the butter, honey and cinnamon. Sprinkle the spinach and scallions evenly over the batter. Use a spoon to press the greens into the batter so they are not all floating on top. ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2021/06/French-fruit-tart-1-scaled.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2021/06/French-fruit-tart-1-scaled-500x500.jpg", "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT40M", "recipeIngredient": ["1  p\u00e2te sucr\u00e9e (sweet tart dough)", "2 cups whole milk ((do not substitute low-fat or skim milk))", "\u00bd cup sugar", "3 tablespoons cornstarch", "1  large egg", "2  large egg yolks", "3 tablespoons unsalted butter, (cut into pieces)", "2 teaspoons vanilla extract", "About 4 cups fresh mixed berries of choice, (plus other fruits, such as sliced kiwi or mango (see note))", "\u00bc cup apricot jam"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the Crust: Complete the\u00a0p\u00e2te sucr\u00e9e\u00a0through baking and cooling.", "name": "Make the Crust: Complete the\u00a0p\u00e2te sucr\u00e9e\u00a0through baking and cooling.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/classic-french-fruit-tart.html#wprm-recipe-77640-step-0-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make the Pastry Cream: In a medium pot, heat the milk until just boiling. Remove the pot from heat. While the milk is warming, in a heat-proof mixing bowl, whisk together the sugar, egg, egg yolks, and cornstarch. Whisk until the mixture is very smooth and has lightened in color, about 2 minutes. Whisking constantly, add about a quarter of the hot milk into the egg mixture. (This is called tempering. Tempering the eggs helps raise their temperature without cooking them, and helps emulsify them into the milk.) Pour the milk-tempered egg mixture into the pot of the remaining milk. Whisk to combine. Return the pot to the heat and cook over medium heat, whisking constantly to prevent \u201cscrambled eggs,\u201d especially on the sides and bottom, until the magic happens and the pastry cream thickens, about 2 minutes. Stir in the butter and vanilla and cook one minute more, whisking constantly. The pastry cream should make thick, lazy bubbles. (See note below if you see any coagulated bits of egg in your custard.) Pour the thickened pastry cream into a clean, shallow bowl. Cover it with plastic wrap and push it down in the bowl so it sits directly on the surface of the pastry cream. This prevents a skin from forming on top. Chill until cold, a few hours (or up to 2 days before serving).", "name": "Make the Pastry Cream: In a medium pot, heat the milk until just boiling. Remove the pot from heat. While the milk is warming, in a heat-proof mixing bowl, whisk together the sugar, egg, egg yolks, and cornstarch. Whisk until the mixture is very smooth and has lightened in color, about 2 minutes. Whisking constantly, add about a quarter of the hot milk into the egg mixture. (This is called tempering. Tempering the eggs helps raise their temperature without cooking them, and helps emulsify them into the milk.) Pour the milk-tempered egg mixture into the pot of the remaining milk. Whisk to combine. Return the pot to the heat and cook over medium heat, whisking constantly to prevent \u201cscrambled eggs,\u201d especially on the sides and bottom, until the magic happens and the pastry cream thickens, about 2 minutes. Stir in the butter and vanilla and cook one minute more, whisking constantly. The pastry cream should make thick, lazy bubbles. (See note below if you see any coagulated bits of egg in your custard.) Pour the thickened pastry cream into a clean, shallow bowl. Cover it with plastic wrap and push it down in the bowl so it sits directly on the surface of the pastry cream. This prevents a skin from forming on top. Chill until cold, a few hours (or up to 2 days before serving).", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/classic-french-fruit-tart.html#wprm-recipe-77640-step-0-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Assemble the Tart: Remove the tart ring and transfer the tart shell to a serving platter. Whisk the chilled pastry cream until smooth, then spread it evenly into the tart shell using an offset spatula. Arrange a generous amount of fruit over the pastry cream in your desired design. In a small saucepan, heat the apricot jam with 1 tablespoon of water over medium heat, whisking, until thin. (Alternatively, heat it in a heat-proof bowl in the microwave for about 30 seconds.) If the jam is especially chunky, strain it through a sieve. Use a pastry brush to gently dab the fruit with a thin layer of apricot glaze. Chill until ready to serve.", "name": "Assemble the Tart: Remove the tart ring and transfer the tart shell to a serving platter. Whisk the chilled pastry cream until smooth, then spread it evenly into the tart shell using an offset spatula. Arrange a generous amount of fruit over the pastry cream in your desired design. In a small saucepan, heat the apricot jam with 1 tablespoon of water over medium heat, whisking, until thin. (Alternatively, heat it in a heat-proof bowl in the microwave for about 30 seconds.) If the jam is especially chunky, strain it through a sieve. Use a pastry brush to gently dab the fruit with a thin layer of apricot glaze. Chill until ready to serve.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/classic-french-fruit-tart.html#wprm-recipe-77640-step-0-2"}], "recipeCategory": ["Cakes, Pies &amp; Tarts", "Dessert", "Fruit"], "recipeCuisine": ["French"], "keywords": "fruit tart", "nutrition": {"@type": "NutritionInformation", "calories": "349 kcal", "fatContent": "16 g", "carbohydrateContent": "47 g", "proteinContent": "5 g", "saturatedFatContent": "10 g", "sugarContent": "29 g", "fiberContent": "2 g", "sodiumContent": "95 mg", "cholesterolContent": "108 mg", "servingSize": "1 serving"}, "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/classic-french-fruit-tart.html#recipe", "isPartOf": {"@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/classic-french-fruit-tart.html#article"}, "mainEntityOfPage": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/classic-french-fruit-tart.html"}]}, {"@context": "https://slickstream.com", "@graph": [{"@type": "Plugin", "version": "3.0.1"}, {"@type": "Site", "name": "Once Upon a Chef", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com", "description": "Tested &amp; ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, whisk the eggs yolks with 1 teaspoon of water.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dust a clean work surface with flour and place one of the sheets of puff pastry on top. Sprinkle the pastry with flour as well. Using a rolling pin, roll the dough into a 12-inch square, flattening the seams with the rolling pin as you go. Using a pizza cutter or sharp knife, trim the edges so that they are straight. Cut the pastry into a grid, with strips about 1\u00bc inches wide and 2\u00bc inches long. You\u2019ll be making about 8 vertical cuts and 4 horizontal cuts in the pastry (see the picture above for a visual reference; you'll need at least 40 strips and you may have extra).", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Working with one row at a time, starting at the bottom of the \"grid,\" brush the bottom inch of the strips with the egg mixture. Set a cocktail sausage parallel to the egg mixture at the top end of the first pastry strip. Roll the sausage up into its dough \"blanket,\" and press the free edge onto the blanket to seal it closed. The dough should overlap slightly on itself. Place the pig in a blanket, seam-side down, on one of the prepared baking sheets. Repeat with the remaining strips, setting them on the lined pan about 1-inch apart once rolled. Place the pigs in a blanket in the refrigerator. Discard any leftover pastry, wipe the work surface clean to remove any egg, and then dust with flour and repeat with the remaining pastry sheet and cocktail sausages. (There is no need to refrigerate the second batch, unless you don't plan on baking them right away. The pigs in a blanket can be made up to 4 hours ahead of time, covered with plastic wrap, and refrigerated before baking.)", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush the pigs in a blanket lightly with the remaining egg mixture, and then place the sheet pans in the oven and bake for 25 to 30 minutes, rotating the pans from top to bottom and back to front midway through, until the pastry is golden. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, make the sauce: In a small bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise, mustard, honey, Tabasco, and vinegar.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer the pigs in a blanket to a serving platter and serve warm with the sauce.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Note: Puff pastry dough is easiest to work with when cold, so work in batches, making the first batch (from one sheet of dough) before taking the second sheet of dough out of the refrigerator.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make-Ahead/Freezer-Friendly Instructions: The pigs in a blanket can be assembled up to 4 hours ahead of time, covered with plastic wrap, and refrigerated before baking. They can also be frozen until firm, then stored in freezer bags up to one month ahead. They can be put in the oven directly from the freezer; they may just take an additional minute or 2 in the oven.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pigs-in-a-blanket.html#fv-recipe-step-10"}], "recipeIngredient": ["2 (14 oz) packages cocktail sausages (I use Hillshire Farm Lit'l Smokies)", "2  large egg yolks", "1 (1-pound) box frozen puff pastry, thawed (I use Pepperidge Farm; see note)", " All-purpose flour, for rolling the pastry", "\u00bc cup mayonnaise, best quality such as Hellmann's or Duke's", "2 tablespoons grainy Dijon mustard", "1 tablespoon honey", "2 teaspoons Tabasco sauce", "2 teaspoons red wine vinegar"], "recipeYield": "About 80 and \u00bd cup of sauce", "image": ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2020/10/Pigs-in-a-Blanket-1200x1829.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2020/10/Pigs-in-a-Blanket-scaled-500x500.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2020/10/Pigs-in-a-Blanket-scaled-500x375.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2020/10/Pigs-in-a-Blanket-scaled-480x270.jpg"], "citation": "Inspired by a recipe in <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Cook-Me-Recipes-Home-Cookbook/dp/0593135083\">Cook with Me: 150 Recipes for the Home Cook</a> by Alex Guarnaschelli", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "ratingValue": 4.96, "ratingCount": "69"}, "datePublished": "2023-12-28T08:48:30-05:00", "keywords": "Bar Food, Christmas, Halloween, New Year's Eve, Puff Pastry, Sausage, Thanksgiving", "recipeCuisine": "American", "recipeCategory": "Recipes"}]

The almond flour gets heavy and soggy and the cup for cup is grainy in crumble toppings. Instead I add an equal quantity of toasted chopped pecans, not too finely chopped, but in smallish bits. Or experiment with the size you prefer.  \r\n\r\nIt is not the same, it does not form clumps in the identical way as flour but the pecans are crunchy, and toasting them adds a warm nutty flavor which is perfect in this or any crumble. Yum!!!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Michelle C"}, "datePublished": "2023-03-01"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "This was a huge hit at Christmas, with adults and small kids alike (vanilla ice cream is a must!). I reheated before serving as suggested, 10-15 min at 300 and it was perfectly warmed. Modifications: reduced both brown and white sugars down to a scant cup each (just reduce your white sugar according to the sweetness of your apples - I used mostly very tart granny smith so didn't want to reduce too much), reduced cinnamon to 1 heaping teaspoon and added 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg, used dairy free Earth Balance unsalted butter bars for our dairy free family members, and added 1 cup of chopped walnuts to the crumble - soooo good! It was officially named \"Gruffalo Crumble\" (in reference to a children's book) by the littles at the table and I know this recipe will become a yummy tradition. Not a single one of Jenn's recipes that I have tried (and I've made a couple dozen) have failed to please everyone, don't skip this one! And other commenters are right, when you come into the kitchen the next morning and lay eyes on this crumble, please sneak those bites with your coffee or tea - truly delicious. Thank you, Jenn, for your totally refined and approachable recipes for all parts of life :).", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Julia"}, "datePublished": "2023-01-02"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Awesome, crumble. ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/about-jenn-segal"]}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640052977", "position": 1, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640052977", "name": "What kind of turkey should I buy?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "There are a few types of turkeys you\u2019ll typically see in stores: natural or plain, self-basting or injected, or kosher turkeys. Natural turkeys haven\u2019t been pre-treated in any way, while self-basting and kosher birds have already been salted or injected with a brining solution to keep them juicy.<br/>For most recipes (including the one below), a plain, untreated turkey gives you the most control over seasoning. That said, if you can only find a self-basting or kosher bird, don\u2019t worry\u2014you can absolutely still make any turkey recipe. Just keep in mind that these birds already contain salt, so if using a brine, you may want to dial back the salt to avoid over-salting.<br/>You may also come across organic, free-range, or heritage turkeys, which usually have excellent flavor but can be leaner and cook a little faster.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640077572", "position": 2, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640077572", "name": "How much turkey should I count on per person?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "A good rule of thumb is about 1\u00bd to 2 pounds of turkey per person if you\u2019re buying a whole bird. That accounts for both the bones and the meat. If you want plenty of leftovers for sandwiches or soups the next day, lean toward the higher end of that range. For example, a 14-pound turkey comfortably serves about 8 to 10 people with leftovers.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640099075", "position": 3, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640099075", "name": "How long should a frozen turkey thaw?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "The safest method is to let the turkey thaw slowly in the refrigerator. Plan on about 24 hours of thawing time for every 4 pounds of turkey. So, for a bird in the 12 to 14 pound range, you\u2019ll want to start the process 3 to 4 days before roasting. This steady, hands-off approach keeps the meat at a safe temperature as it defrosts.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640115397", "position": 4, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640115397", "name": "Should I rinse my turkey?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Nope\u2014it\u2019s best not to. Rinsing a raw turkey can actually spread bacteria around your sink and counters. Any surface bacteria will cook off in the oven, so just pat the bird dry with paper towels before brining or seasoning.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640138737", "position": 5, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640138737", "name": "What's the difference between wet and dry brining?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Dry brining involves rubbing salt, herbs, and spices onto the turkey skin and letting it rest in the fridge overnight (or longer). In contrast, wet brining requires soaking the turkey in a seasoned saltwater solution, which often means dealing with a large cooler or bag\u2014a process that can be quite cumbersome. Both methods enhance flavor and juiciness, but dry brining is much simpler and produces beautifully crisp skin.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640159060", "position": 6, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640159060", "name": "Should the turkey be roasted with the stuffing inside?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "It\u2019s best to cook the stuffing separately rather than inside the turkey. Not only does this reduce food safety risks (since the stuffing needs to reach a safe temperature along with the meat), but it also ensures the stuffing comes out golden and crisp on top instead of soggy. Bonus: your turkey will also cook more evenly and a bit faster.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640183404", "position": 7, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640183404", "name": "Should I tie the turkey legs together or keep them clipped/trussed?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "If your turkey comes with the legs tucked into a metal or plastic clip, or held together by a small flap of skin, it\u2019s best to remove it before roasting. Leaving the legs bound prevents heat from circulating properly, which can cause the inner thighs to cook more slowly. Let the legs rest naturally\u2014this helps the turkey cook more evenly and ensures the meat near the cavity is fully done.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640200113", "position": 8, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640200113", "name": "Should I baste my turkey?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "You don\u2019t need to\u2014and honestly, it can do more harm than good. Every time you open the oven to baste, you let out heat and extend the cooking time. Plus, basting doesn\u2019t actually make the meat juicier; it just helps the skin brown. A dry-brined turkey already has plenty of flavor and moisture built in, and the butter rub before roasting gives you that beautifully golden, crisp skin without all the fuss.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640234656", "position": 9, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640234656", "name": "How much time does a turkey need to roast?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "It depends on the size of the bird, but generally you\u2019ll be looking at a few hours. Smaller turkeys cook more quickly at a steady temperature, while larger ones benefit from a two-stage method\u2014starting at a higher temperature to brown the skin, then lowering the heat so the meat cooks evenly.<br/><br/>Rather than relying strictly on minutes per pound, it\u2019s best to use a thermometer: the breast should register <strong>165\u00b0F</strong> and the thighs <strong>175\u00b0F</strong> when done. Keep in mind that the temperature will rise several degrees as the turkey rests (carryover cooking).<br/><br/>To avoid any guesswork, use a <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/ThermoPro-Digital-Cooking-Thermometer-Stainless/dp/B017613C3C/ref=sr_1_1?s=home-garden&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1481656902&amp;sr=1-1&amp;keywords=leave%2Bin%2Bcooking%2Bthermometer&amp;th=1\">digital thermometer</a> with a leave-in probe and remote monitor so you can track the temperature without ever opening the oven.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640286411", "position": 10, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640286411", "name": "Where should I check the turkey\u2019s temperature?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "To check the breast, insert the thermometer into the deepest part of the meat, holding it parallel to the bird from the neck end. Avoid touching the bone\u2014it can give a false high reading. For the thigh, insert the thermometer into the thickest part of the meat near the hip joint, again avoiding the bone.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640305697", "position": 11, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640305697", "name": "Should the turkey be covered while it roasts?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Not at the start. The bird should go into the oven uncovered so the skin can dry out and crisp as it cooks. After about 90 minutes, if the skin is browning too quickly, the turkey can be tented loosely with foil to prevent it from getting too dark before the meat is fully cooked. This approach gives you the best of both worlds: beautifully golden skin and evenly cooked, juicy meat.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640334966", "position": 12, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640334966", "name": "How long should the turkey rest before carving?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "At least 20 to 30 minutes. This gives the juices time to redistribute, keeping the meat moist when you carve it. Cover it loosely with foil to keep it warm\u2014the internal temperature will continue to rise slightly as it rests.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640346787", "position": 13, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#faq-question-1762640346787", "name": "Can turkey be roasted ahead of time?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes, you can absolutely roast it in advance to make the big day less hectic. Just keep in mind that the skin won\u2019t stay as crisp once it\u2019s reheated, but the meat will still be tender and flavorful. "HowToStep", "text": "Remove and discard the truss that holds turkey legs together (if the legs are held together with turkey skin, cut the skin to release them). Pat the turkey dry with paper towels.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, mix the sugar, salt, thyme, sage, and pepper for the dry brine. Place the turkey on the rack of the prepared baking sheet. Rub and pat the dry brine all over the turkey, including inside the cavity. Refrigerate, uncovered, for at least 24 hours and up to 48 hours. (For food safety, ensure the turkey remains in the refrigerator at 40\u00b0F or lower during the entire brining period. If brining for longer than 24 hours, you can cover the turkey loosely with plastic wrap for the first part of the brining process and then uncover it for the final 24 hours to allow the skin to dry.)", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F and set an oven rack in the lower third of the oven. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roast the turkey until the skin is deep golden and a leave-in or instant-read thermometer registers 165\u00b0F (74\u00b0C) in the thickest part of the breast and 175\u00b0F (80\u00b0C) in the thigh, 1\u00be to 2\u00bd hours. Check the turkey after about 1\u00bd hours; if the skin is browning too quickly, cover it loosely with foil.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using clean oven mitts that you don't mind getting dirty (silicone grilling gloves or mitts work well), carefully tilt the turkey so any juices from the cavity pour into the roasting pan. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "<strong>Make-Ahead Instructions:</strong> If you don't mind losing the crispy skin, the turkey can be roasted and carved ahead of time. Pour a thin layer of the gravy into an ovenproof serving dish. Arrange the carved turkey nicely on top of the gravy; cover tightly with plastic wrap and refrigerate for up to two days. Refrigerate the remaining gravy in a separate container. To reheat: remove the plastic wrap and cover the platter with aluminum foil. Place in a 325\u00b0F-oven for 20 to 30 minutes, until the turkey is hot. Reheat the gravy in the microwave or on the stovetop.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "<strong>Note on Selecting Your Turkey:</strong> For the best results with this dry-brining method, look for a turkey that is not injected, kosher, or labeled as \"self-basting.\" These types of turkeys have already been treated with salt or a brining solution. However, if your bird has been treated, you can absolutely still use this recipe, as these birds do still benefit from additional seasoning. Just halve the amount of salt in the dry brine to avoid over-salting.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/thanksgiving-turkey.html#fv-recipe-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "<strong>Note:</strong> I've given a range for the cooking time, which will depend on the size of your turkey. {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@id": "ouac-fv-recipe-37306", "@type": "Recipe", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jennifer Segal "}, "name": "Pickled Red Onions", "description": "Pickled red "", "sugarContent": "", "fiberContent": "", "sodiumContent": "", "cholesterolContent": ""}, "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small nonreactive saucepan, bring the vinegar, sugar, and salt to a boil. Stir until the sugar and salt are dissolved. Remove the pan from the heat, and add the onion to the pan. Let sit, stirring occasionally, until the onion slices are softened, 10 to 15 minutes. Transfer the onions to a medium jar and pour the vinegar mixture over the top. Press the onions down so that they are completely submerged. Let sit for at least 30 minutes before using. Cover the jar and store in the refrigerator for up to a week.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/pickled-red-onions.html#fv-recipe-step-1"}], "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup apple cider vinegar", "6 tablespoons sugar", "1 tablespoon salt", "1 large red onion, cut into \u215b-inch slices"], "recipeYield": "1 ({24-oz|680-g} jar", "image": ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2024/05/002_PickOnion_031.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2024/05/002_PickOnion_031-500x500.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2024/05/002_PickOnion_031-500x375.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2024/05/002_PickOnion_031-480x270.jpg"], "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "ratingValue": 4.33, "ratingCount": "6"}, "datePublished": "2024-05-02T07:13:40-04:00", "keywords": "All Seasons, Bbq", "recipeCuisine": "American", "recipeCategory": "Recipes"}]

Cook for 5 to 7 minutes, turning the florets every couple of minutes to brown as many surfaces as possible\u2014since cauliflower doesn\u2019t have flat sides, rotate each piece occasionally so it gets golden and crisp all over. Using tongs, flip the ribs over and spoon another \u2153 of the sauce over top. Reserve the remaining BBQ sauce to spoon over the cooked ribs. Cover the pan with aluminum foil and roast for 2\u00bd hours. Remove the foil and, if the cooking liquid is covering the meat, use a  large spoon or ladle to remove some of the liquid so that the tops are exposed. (Note: the meat will look unappetizing at this stage; don't worry, it will look much better once it's done!) Cook for 30 minutes more, uncovered, until the meat is tender and browned. Cut off any excess fat that remains around the short ribs. Transfer the short ribs to a serving platter. Discard the cooking liquid, as it will be very greasy. "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/crispy-roasted-sweet-potatoes.html#faq-question-1698841538726", "name": "What is the science behind adding baking soda to the cooking water?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "When baking soda is added to the boiling water, it raises the pH level, making the water more alkaline. This increased alkalinity weakens the pectin in the potato cells, leading to a breakdown of the potato's surface. As a result, the edges of the potatoes become softer and rougher. When roasted, these rough edges crisp up more effectively, giving you that desirable crispy exterior.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/crispy-roasted-sweet-potatoes.html#faq-question-1698841629069", "position": 2, "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/crispy-roasted-sweet-potatoes.html#faq-question-1698841629069", "name": "I've never cooked with potato starch; where do I find it in the supermarket?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "In most stores, you can find potato starch in the baking aisle alongside other starches and thickeners like cornstarch. It may also be in the gluten-free or international foods aisle, especially within the Kosher or Asian sections. Some stores that have distinct sections for natural or organic foods might also stock potato starch there. {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@id": "ouac-fv-recipe-31579", "@type": "Recipe", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jennifer Segal"}, "name": "Easy Homemade Stromboli Recipe", "description": "This easy stromboli is packed with Italian meats, cheese, and plenty of flavor\u2014perfect for game day or any casual gathering!", "prepTime": "PT25M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT1H", "nutrition": {"@type": "NutritionInformation", "servingSize": "", "calories": "418", "fatContent": "19 g", "carbohydrateContent": "39 g", "proteinContent": "21 g", "saturatedFatContent": "9 g", "unsaturatedFatContent": "", "sugarContent": "1 g", "fiberContent": "2 g", "sodiumContent": "1,169 mg", "cholesterolContent": "77 mg"}, "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line a 13x18-inch baking sheet with parchment paper.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/stromboli.html#fv-recipe-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a lightly floured work surface, stretch and/or roll the dough into a 10x12-inch rectangle, about \u00bc-inch thick. (Be sure not to roll the dough too thin.)", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/stromboli.html#fv-recipe-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange the dough rectangle so the long side is closest to you. Brush the surface with the oil, leaving a 1-inch border around the edges. Spread the garlic evenly over the top of the oil, then sprinkle with the oregano, a pinch of red pepper flakes (if using), and the pecorino romano. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/stromboli.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Shingle the provolone slices evenly over the pecorino romano, followed by the ham, mozzarella, and cured meats. Brush the borders of the dough with the egg (reserve the remaining egg for brushing the top of the stromboli). Fold the bottom third of the stromboli in toward the middle. Fold the top third of stromboli down to cover first fold, creating a wide log, like a folded letter. Pinch the seam tightly to seal. Transfer the stromboli to the prepared baking sheet, seam side down. Pinch the ends tightly to seal and tuck underneath the stromboli. Loosely cover the stromboli with plastic wrap and let rise at room temperature for 1 hour. (The stromboli won't look much different after the rise; that's okay.)", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/stromboli.html#fv-recipe-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F and set an oven rack in the middle position.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/stromboli.html#fv-recipe-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush the top of the dough with the remaining egg. Using a sharp knife, make 5 evenly spaced \u00bd-inch-deep slits, 1\u00bd inches long, on top of the stromboli. Bake until golden brown, puffy, and bubbling, about 35 minutes (if you have a thermometer, the center should register 200\u00b0F). Some grease or cheese may bubble out of the sides and top; that's normal. Use a paper towel to blot any excess grease on the baking sheet. Let the stromboli cool on the baking sheet for 15 to 20 minutes, then transfer to a cutting board and cut into 1-inch-thick slices. Serve warm or at room temperature, with marinara sauce on the side (if using).", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/stromboli.html#fv-recipe-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Note: If you're using the <a href=\"https://www.onceuponachef.com/how-to/pizza-dough-recipe.html\">homemade pizza dough,</a> you'll only need 1 lb. of it for the stromboli. You can either cut the recipe in half or make the whole recipe and refrigerate or freeze the other dough ball.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/stromboli.html#fv-recipe-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Make Ahead/Freezer-Friendly Instructions: The stromboli can be prepared, covered with plastic wrap, and refrigerated for up to 12 hours before baking. Add the egg wash and cut slits right before baking, and allow a few extra minutes in the oven. To freeze the stromboli before baking, fill and roll the stromboli as directed but do not add the egg wash or cut slits. Wrap tightly in plastic wrap and aluminum foil and freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw overnight in the refrigerator. Add the egg wash and cut slits right before baking, and allow a few extra minutes in the oven.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/stromboli.html#fv-recipe-step-8"}], "recipeIngredient": ["1 lb homemade or store-bought pizza dough (see note)", "1 teaspoon extra-virgin olive oil", "1 clove garlic, minced", "\u00bc teaspoon dried oregano", " A few pinches crushed red pepper flakes (optional)", "3 tablespoons finely grated pecorino romano", "4 thin slices (3 oz) provolone cheese", "4 medium slices (3 oz) deli ham", "4  thin slices (3 oz) mozzarella cheese", "14  thin, large slices (3 oz) Italian cured meats, such as salami, pepperoni, bresaola, etc. (use at least two different kinds for best results)", "1 egg, beaten", " Store-bought or homemade marinara sauce, for serving (optional)"], "recipeYield": "4 to 6", "image": ["https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2021/12/Stromboli-15-1200x1375.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2021/12/Stromboli-15-500x500.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2021/12/Stromboli-15-500x375.jpg", "https://www.onceuponachef.com/images/2021/12/Stromboli-15-480x270.jpg"], "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "ratingValue": 4.91, "ratingCount": "32"}, "datePublished": "2022-02-03T08:14:40-05:00", "keywords": "All Seasons, Better-Than-Take Out, Cheese, Comfort Food, Game Day, Potluck", "recipeCuisine": "Italian", "recipeCategory": "Recipes"}]

Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/walnut-cinnamon-biscotti.html#fv-recipe-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cornmeal, baking powder, salt, pepper and cinnamon.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/walnut-cinnamon-biscotti.html#fv-recipe-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In the bowl of an electric mixer, cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy, about 2 minutes. Add the egg and vanilla and beat until well incorporated. Add the flour mixture and walnuts and mix on low speed until just combined. Wrap the dough in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 15 minutes.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/walnut-cinnamon-biscotti.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the dough from the refrigerator and divide it in two. Directly on the lined baking sheet, form each portion into logs about 1\u00bd inches wide and \u00be-inch tall. (If the dough is sticky, dust your hands with flour.) Leave about 4 inches of space between the logs to allow the dough to spread. Bake for 20 minutes, then remove from the oven and let cool for 10 minutes. Once cool, transfer the cookie logs to a cutting board. Using a serrated knife and a sawing motion, cut the logs diagonally into generous \u00bd-inch slices. (They will look a little undercooked in the middle.) Arrange the cookies, cut side down, back on the lined baking sheet; return to the oven and cook for 5 to 7 minutes, until lightly golden on the underside. Remove the biscotti from the oven and flip over; cook 5 to 7 minutes more, until lightly golden all over. Let cool on the baking sheet completely before serving.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/walnut-cinnamon-biscotti.html#fv-recipe-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "The cookies will keep in an airtight container for up to a month.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/walnut-cinnamon-biscotti.html#fv-recipe-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "<strong>Freezer-Friendly Instructions:</strong> To freeze the dough: Shape into logs, wrap each securely in plastic wrap, and place them in a sealable bag. When ready to bake, remove the logs from the freezer, thaw the dough until pliable, and then proceed with recipe. To freeze after baking: After the cookies are completely cooled, double-wrap them securely with aluminum foil or plastic freezer wrap. Thaw overnight on the countertop before serving. "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 300\u00b0F and set an oven rack in the middle position. Lightly grease two round 8-in cake pans with nonstick cooking spray. Line the pans with parchment rounds, and then spray again.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/shortbread-cookies.html#fv-recipe-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the paddle attachment or beaters, combine the butter, sugar, salt, vanilla extract, and almond extract. Beat until smooth and creamy, about 1 minute. Add the flour beat on low speed until the dough comes together in a cohesive mass. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/shortbread-cookies.html#fv-recipe-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the dough in half (if you have a scale, each half will weigh about 10.5 oz). Dust your hands with flour and press each half into an even layer in the prepared pans, dusting your hands with more flour as necessary to prevent the dough from sticking. To smooth the surface, place a piece of plastic wrap over the dough and smooth with your hands. Use a fork to prick the dough all over in 1-inch intervals to allow steam to escape while the shortbread bakes. ", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/shortbread-cookies.html#fv-recipe-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the shortbread until it's a light golden brown across the top surface, and a deeper golden brown around the edges, about 35 minutes.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/shortbread-cookies.html#fv-recipe-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the pans from the oven, and let cool on a rack for about 10 minutes. Run a blunt knife around the edges of the pan to loosen the shortbread, and then carefully turn each round out of the pans, using your hand to gently lower the shortbread onto a cutting board. Using a sharp knife, cut each round into 8 or 10 wedges. (Do this while the shortbread is still warm; otherwise, it won't cut easily and will crumble.) Transfer the shortbread wedges to a rack to finish cooling. Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 1 month, or freeze for longer storage.", "url": "https://www.onceuponachef.com/recipes/shortbread-cookies.html#fv-recipe-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "<strong>Freezer-Friendly Instructions:</strong> The shortbread dough can be frozen for up to 3 months. After mixing, shape the dough into 2 disks, wrap each securely in plastic wrap, and place them in a sealable bag. Thaw overnight before baking. To freeze the shortbread after baking, store in an airtight container separating layers with parchment paper or aluminum foil. Thaw at room temperature before serving. After breading the fish sticks with flour, eggs, and panko, lay them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Freeze them on the baking sheet until they're solid, then transfer to a freezer-safe bag or container. They can be stored for up to 3 months. When you're ready to cook, allow them to defrost slightly so they'll lay flat in the pan, then follow the cooking instructions. "Crispy Pan Fried Fish Fingers", "description": "Prepare a fun hands-on weeknight dinner with these pan fried fish fingers \u2014 juicy on the inside, golden and crusty outside, with delicious lemon-garlic mayo for dipping.", "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT1H", "nutrition": {"@type": "NutritionInformation", "servingSize": "", "calories": "", "fatContent": "",
